title: How to prove this Boolean expression, (A+C) + (B+D') =AC'+B'D - Quora

response.answer_text: As others have rightly pointed out in the case where A,B and C are true the left hand must be true and the right hand must be false so the statements are not equivalent. However, in general Boolean identities are so much easier to prove than ordinary algebraic identities. All you do is hammer out a truth table. If you have one variable you have 2^1 rows in your truth table, if you have 2 variables you have 2^2 rows etc. In this case you’d have 2^4 or 16 rows covering all 16 possible combinations. First let’s see how it’s supposed to work. Let’s prove an identity we know is true: (A.B)' = A' + B' This is called DeMorgan’s Law but it doesn’t matter if some clever person said it, it’s not true unless it’s proved to be true. Appeals to authority are invalid arguments. So forget who said it, let’s prove it’s true. In any form of mathematics a statement is true if it holds true for all permissible values that a variable can hold but in Boolean algebra a variable can only hold two values, that is 0 or 1 or True or False or On or Off or however you want to word it. 0 = false = off and 1 = true = on. Listing all possible combinations then is easy.  A truth table however doesn’t just prove a relationship is valid, it can also prove a relationship invalid. If the two columns do no match up then the two statements are not equivalent. So if you ever get into a situation where you want to know if statement 1 is equivalent to statement 2, just draw a truth table of all possible combinations.
